document.docAuthor: Barbosa, Julianna Freires & Nessimian, Jorge Luiz
document.masterDocTitle: The genus Buenoa Kirkaldy, 1904 (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Nepomorpha: Notonectidae) in northern Brazil: inventory, new records, and new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The genus Buenoa Kirkaldy, 1904 (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Nepomorpha: Notonectidae) in northern Brazil: inventory, new records, and new species

figureCitation.captionText: FIGURES 63 – 71. 63 – 65. Buenoa amnigenopsis Nieser. 63, Lateral view of male rostrum with rostral prong longer than third rostral segment; 64, Ventral view of male fore leg with femur notched, without stridulatory area, and similar teeth on tibia; 65, Claspers. Scale bar: 0.5 mm. 66 – 68. Buenoa amnigenus (White). 66, Lateral view of male rostrum with rostral prong longer than third rostral segment; 67, Ventral view of male fore leg without stridulatory area on femur and similar teeth on tibia; 68, Claspers. 69 – 71. Buenoa salutis Kirkaldy. 69, Lateral view of male rostrum with rostral prong equal to or slightly longer than third rostral segment; 70, Ventral view of male fore leg without stridulatory area on femur and slightly dissimilar teeth on tibia; 71, Claspers. Scale bar: 0.5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Buenoa salutis Kirkaldy, 1904 : 124
[ Type locality: Isle du Salut, French Guyana ; Type in Muséum National D’histoire Naturelle ( France )]; Kirkaldy and Torre-Bueno ( 1909 ): 201 [French Guyana ]; Truxal ( 1953 ): 1469 [Revision; Distribution and records: Venezuela , Guyana , French Guyana , Brazil , Bolivia , Paraguay ]; Truxal ( 1957 ): 17 [Systematics; expedition in Goiás and Tocantins, Brazil ]; Bachmann ( 1962 ): 24 [Record: Delta del Paraná ( Argentina )]; Nieser ( 1968 ): 127 [Records: Suriname , Venezuela , Argentina ]; Nieser ( 1970 ): 86 [Records: Venezuela , Brazil ]; Bachmann ( 1971 ): 606 [Records: Paraguay , Argentina ]; Roback and Nieser ( 1974 ): 45 [Survey: Colombia ]; Nieser ( 1975 ): 192 [Record: Suriname ]; Nieser and Alkins-Koo ( 1991 ): 35 [Survey: Trinidad and Tobago ]; Nieser and Melo ( 1997 ): 77 [Key to
Buenoa
of Minas Gerais, Brazil ]; Bachmann ( 1998 ): 179 [ Argentina ]; Heckman ( 1998 a): 254 [Survey: Pantanal ( Brazil )]; Heckman ( 1998 b): 39 [Survey: Pantanal ( Brazil )]; Estévez et al. ( 2003 ): 371 [Survey: Esteros del Iberá ( Argentina )]; López Ruf et al . ( 2003 ): 68 [Survey: Parque Nacional Mburucuyá ( Argentina )]; Melo and Nieser ( 2004 ): 45 [Faunistical notes; survey: Januária ( Brazil )]; Herrera Millán ( 2005 ): 118 [Survey: Venezuela ]; Torres et al. ( 2007 ): 147 [Survey: Parque Nacional El Palmar ( Argentina )]; Mazzucconi ( 2008 ): 221 [Note: Argentina ]; Mazzucconi et al. ( 2008 ): 61 [ Argentina ]; Morales-Castaño and Molano-Rendón ( 2008 ): 124 [Survey: Quindió ( Colombia )]; Heckman ( 2011 ): 482 [Key to
Buenoa
of South America ]; Moreira et al . ( 2011 ): 55 [Check-list of Brazil ].

Buenoa mallochi : Jaczewski ( 1928 )
: 129 [Synonymy; Type locality: Brazil , Paraná, Vermelho; Types were in Warsaw Museum ( Poland ) 9 ].

Comments.
Buenoa salutis
is the smallest species of the genus, at the largest about 4.0 mm in length. This species resembles
B. konta
(see comments from the previous species) and
B. amnigenus
.
Buenoa salutis
and
B. amnigenus
have a sympatric distribution, occurring from Trinidad and Tobago to Argentina . These species are similar in general appearance and in typical characteristics of the group: vertex broad, synthlipsis narrow, stridulatory area of fore femur absent, and fore tibia with parallel margins.

Buenoa salutis
differs from
B. amnigenus
by its reduced size, a broader synthlipsis, the frons broad, the tylus flat, the apex of the rostral prong sinuous (
Fig. 69
), and the stridulatory teeth of the fore tibia of similar size (
Fig. 70
).
Buenoa amnigenus
has a distinctly greater length, the synthlipsis conspicuously narrow, the frons narrow, the tylus not inflated athough rounded, the apex of rostral prong rounded (
Fig. 66
), and stridulatory teeth on the fore tibia increasing in size toward the apex (
Fig. 67
).

This species is often collected with specimens of
B. amnigenus
and, less frequently, with specimens of
B. amnigenopsis
.
